industry_definition: The Online Sporting Goods Sales industry includes online stores that retail new sporting goods...

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators primarily sell sporting goods equipment, but also retail hunting and fishing products, for example.

FAQs.question: Do your company's advertising campaigns target a wide range of consumers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators market to consumers of all ages.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators work directly with manufacturers to manage purchase costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease equipment to reduce overhead costs?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators either lease warehouses to store inventory or may lease machinery to help with managing inventory.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators rely on POS systems to manage inventories effectively.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have benefited from a rise of online sales.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are not typically impacted significantly by changes in regulations.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators work with national associations and legislators to ensure consumer privacy and consumer data laws are not breached, but protected.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies depending on the size, scope and location of the operator.

FAQs.question: How have volatile input prices affected your profit margin over the past year?
FAQs.answer: While volatility in input prices primarily affects manufacturing operators, industry operators have not been significantly affected by such changes.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor demand for certain products? How do you keep up with demand?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators need to maintain a well-stocked portfolio of products that are currently being demanded on the market.

FAQs.question: What do you do to retain customer loyalty? How do your prices and quality compare with that of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Maintaining a reputation of low price for high quality and offering recognizable brands are important in maintaining repeat buyers.

FAQs.question: What kind of R&D do you undertake? How manageable is your website? Is it easy to navigate?
FAQs.answer: Having an easily navigable website for customers and a reliable security system is critical for industry operators to maintain a consumer base.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor consumer spending? How do you mitigate the potential threat of declining consumer spending?
FAQs.answer: As consumer spending rises, so too does the potential pool of revenue for industry operators.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in the percentage of business conducted online? How do you plan to take advantage of the rise in the percentage of business conducted online?
FAQs.answer: As the percentage of business conducted online increases, so too does demand for products from industry operators.

FAQs.question: How do you track participation in sports? How do you plan to capitalize on expected increases in sports participation?
FAQs.answer: As participation in sports rises, so too does potential revenue and demand for the industry.
